title: How many total major hurricanes (Category 3 or higher) will occur in the Atlantic Ocean in the 2020 hurricane season, according to the National Hurricane Center?

I was monumentally wrong on this one. I looked at past data, adjusted for recent trends and ended up at the wrong end of the spectrum here. For much of the duration of this question I had 0 or near zero in the 6+ bucket. That's not surprising because 6+ had never happened before. Through mid September it seemed like it was going in the direction I predicted, but towards the end of the season a whole series of big storms sprang up. One observation that was interesting to me is that since about mid September the forecasts have consistently underestimated the severity and speed of development of the storms. The ensemble models have consistently seen a rate of storm development that was outside the range of any of the components. By a lot.  That suggests to me that the Atlantic basin hurricane models may need some tweaking to reflect current climatic conditions.  @cafebedouin
Iota is a CAT IV this morning.

“NOAA’s Climate Prediction Center is forecasting a likely range of 13 to 19 named storms (winds of 39 mph or higher), of which 6 to 10 could become hurricanes (winds of 74 mph or higher), including 3 to 6 major hurricanes (category 3, 4 or 5; with winds of 111 mph or higher). NOAA provides these ranges with a 70% confidence. An average hurricane season produces 12 named storms, of which 6 become hurricanes, including 3 major hurricanes” (NOAA, 2020). “Also, warmer-than-average sea surface temperatures in the tropical Atlantic Ocean and Caribbean Sea, coupled with reduced vertical wind shear, weaker tropical Atlantic trade winds, and an enhanced west African monsoon all increase the likelihood for an above-normal Atlantic hurricane season. Similar conditions have been producing more active seasons since the current high-activity era began in 1995” (NOAA, 2020). To date, there have been a total of 26 tropical or subtropical cyclones, 25 named storms, 9 hurricanes, and 3 major hurricanes. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 through November 30 and with only a month and a half left, that leaves plenty of time for more activity.  According to a recent NOAA Press Release to the 2020 Atlantic Hurricane Season Outlook, “the 2020 Atlantic hurricane season has already produced a May-July record of nine named storms, with seven tropical storms and two hurricanes. For the remainder of the season, we expect (with 70% probability for each range) an additional 10-16 named storms, with 5-9 becoming hurricanes and 3-6 of those becoming major hurricanes.”  With this amount of certainty from the leading experts, I will assess a 65% chance that there will be at least one more major hurricane before the end of the official season.

How many total major hurricanes (Category 3 or higher) will occur in the Atlantic Ocean in the 2020 hurricane season, according to the National Hurricane Center?
September:  According to the National Hurricane Center, there have been two tropical storms in the Atlantic Ocean during the 2020 Hurricane Season. Predicting the weather is always difficult and often leads to much frustration for many citizens. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration went on the record in May, 2020 stating, “an above-normal 2020 Atlantic hurricane season is expected according to forecasters with NOAA’s Climate Prediction Center, a division of the National Weather Service” (NOAA, 2020). This was further explained as, 
“NOAA’s Climate Prediction Center is forecasting a likely range of 13 to 19 named storms (winds of 39 or higher), of which 6 to 10 could  become hurricanes (winds of 74 or higher), including 3 to 6 major hurricanes (category 3,4, or 5; with winds of 111 mph or higher). (NOAA, 2020).
As the professionals’ state, it appears that the Atlantic Ocean surrounding states are in for several hurricanes this upcoming season. As of now, I would put 35% chance of four hurricanes, 30% chance of three hurricanes, 15% of two or fewer, and 10% on each prediction of five or six hurricanes. 
October:  As of October 2020, we have had 9 hurricanes, two being considered major hurricanes, according to the Farmer’s Almanac. However, a new hurricane has emerged and it is expected to cause significant damage, “Delta is forecast to emerge into the Gulf of Mexico on Wednesday afternoon and restrengthen  into a Category 3 major hurricane, forecasters said” (Rice, 2020). With Hurricane season almost being complete it is my prediction that we will only have three to four major hurricanes. I put a probability of 52% of three with a probability of 48% of four major hurricanes.

By most estimates, the 2020 hurricane season was expected to be extremely active. As of 5 October 2020 there have been a total of 25 named storms making it the second most active in history (Mitchell, 2020). Three of the 25 storms (Laura, Teddy, and Delta) qualified as major hurricanes reaching Category 3 strength or more with minimum wind speeds of 111 mph (Chinchar 2020; weather.com, 2020; NOAA, 1999). Averaging one hurricane in October annually, a total of 18 major hurricanes have struck the United States in the month of October since 1851 (Lam & Dolce, 2020, NOAA, 2018). With Hurricane Delta arriving relatively early in the month of October and hurricane season not ending until 30 Nov, there is ample time for additional hurricanes to develop. The most hurricanes to develop in the month of October is 5 which took place in 2010 (Lam & Dolce, 2020). 
	While it becomes more difficult for storms to form later in the season as water temperature begins to drop, it is clearly evident hurricanes can develop in late October. The latest documented landfall of a hurricane taking place on 21 Nov 1985. However, these storms often don’t reach category 3 strength. Utilizing current and historical data estimate the following; 0% chance two or fewer major hurricanes, 90% probability for 3 major hurricanes, 9% probability for four major hurricanes, 1% probability for five, and 0% probability that 6 or more major hurricanes take place in the 2020 hurricane season.  https://weather.com/storms/hurricane/news/2020-09-24-hurricane-threat-october-united-states-florida#:~:text=Since%202016%2C%20hurricanes%20Matthew%2C%20Nate,hurricanes%20to%20strike%20the%20U.S. https://weather.com/storms/hurricane/news/2020-09-16-hurricane-teddy-forecast-bermuda-atlantic-canada https://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd-faq/#complete-list-of-landfalling-hurricanes https://www.hsdl.org/?view&did=34038 https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/07/weather/historic-storm-hurricane-delta/index.html https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/outreach/history/

I assess that there will most likely be three (35%) to four (46%) major hurricanes during this hurricane season in the Atlantic Ocean. This leaves a 18% chance of five and 5% chance of six or more major storms.  The 2020 Atlantic hurricane season will be "extremely active," per the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The hurricane season for 2020 in the Atlantic runs from June 1 to November 30 while the Eastern Pacific hurricane season runs from May 15th to November 30th. The Atlantic basin includes the Atlantic Ocean, Caribbean Sea, and the Gulf of Mexico. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has never forecast 25 storms in a single season, typically only producing 12 named storms in a season. Conditions are more conducive to such storms as water temperature and wind shear as key indicators in predicting the strength of a hurricane season. Both of which are higher than average this year. The amount of available moisture versus the volume of disruptive winds is also a primary indicator. 
	As of 10/7, 25 storms have already been named, with 53 days left in the season. Eight hurricanes have developed this season with three upgrading to a major storm. The three major storms were Laura, Teddy, and Delta. Laura tied the 1856 Last Island hurricane in being the most powerful storm to hit the state of Louisiana.  Nine named storms have made landfall within the continental United States. The Greek letter system, resurrected this year, has only been used one other time in 2005. Hurricane Hanna, Isaias, Laura, and Marco have struct the coast in varying degrees, one developing to a category four storm. Total damage is placed over $24 billion with nearly 145 fatalities. Models show that mid-September to November is typically the apex of hurricane activity. Therefore, the season is slowly winding down yet still has the potential to produce another major storm. Thus, three to four major hurricanes will likely occur resulting in a total of four to five major hurricanes for this the entire season, one of the most active on record.

“60% chance of an above-normal season, a 30% chance of a near-normal season and only a 10% chance of a below-normal season. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 through November 30… NOAA’s Climate Prediction Center is forecasting a likely range of 13 to 19 named storms (winds of 39 mph or higher), of which 6 to 10 could become hurricanes (winds of 74 mph or higher), including 3 to 6 major hurricanes (category 3, 4 or 5; with winds of 111 mph or higher). NOAA provides these ranges with a 70% confidence. An average hurricane season produces 12 named storms, of which 6 become hurricanes, including 3 major hurricanes.” (NOAA, 2020) Three major hurricanes a year is the average hurricane season.  NOAA predicts 3-6 major hurricanes.  However, as of 30 September, while the number of named storms is above average at 23, there have only been eight hurricanes, two of which were major (Laura and Teddy), and one of these (Teddy) never made landfall in the U.S. (Scott, 2020). In order for there to be an “above average” year, two more major hurricanes would have to form between now and 30 November. What is the likelihood that this occurs?  What is the probability of major hurricanes forming in October and November? “From mid-August through mid-October, the activity spikes, accounting for 78 percent of the tropical storm days, 87 percent of the category 1 and 2 hurricane days (Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale), and a whopping 96 percent of the major (category 3, 4 and 5) hurricane days.” (NOAA, 2016) In other words, the most dangerous period for forming major hurricanes will be over in 12 days, after which major hurricane activity becomes extremely unlikely. In fact, it is likely that if a next major hurricane occurs in this period, it is currently being tracked as a tropical storm or a tropical depression. There are two storms currently in the Atlantic.  Neither of these are likely to become anything stronger than they already are.  The only other storm is north of Venezuela and has a 60% chance of cyclone formation and may very well become a tropical depression.  But it is already too close to land, and it is likely to run into Tropical Storm Gamma (which is moving southeast).  This may strengthen Tropical Storm Gamma, but it’s only like to make Gamma a hurricane, not reach major hurricane status. Due to the lack of a qualifying candidate for major hurricane being present, and the end of the peak time for major hurricanes occurring on 15 October, I am forecasting with 80% confidence that this year’s hurricane season will have only two major hurricanes, with 19% for three major hurricanes and a 1% chance of four or more major hurricanes. The Delphi Method was used for discussion and predictions for this question. Our initial prediction was 3 hurricanes this season in the Atlantic that will be Category 3 or above. After discussion, judging off our experience living on a popular hurricane affected zone, the National Hurricane Center statistics and radar, history, and current conditions, we maintained our prediction of 3 hurricanes. Weather forecasting changes so rapidly that you can only actually accurately predict two days out. Because we are not God and cannot see the future, the past and current conditions lead us to maintain the 3 still. Taking major hurricane data from 2000 to this year, we see there have been an average of 3.3 a year since then. Furthermore, taking the distribution of major hurricanes by month, we see that they occur between June to November, with 24% in August, 41% in September, and 21% in October. Currently this year, we have had 1.
I approach this problem by modeling hurricanes over the course of a year using a Poisson distribution with rate parameter 3.3. This year, we have just over half the season remaining and one hurricane currently, which means the distributions of hurricanes by the end of the year would be a Poisson distribution with rate parameter .53*3.3, plus 1, for the hurricane that already happened. This distribution yields the percentages I inputted

The report also suggests that there is on average 2.6 major hurricanes (category 3 and above) per year and with a standard deviation of 1.94. Adjustments:
Skew:
@pchi pointed out correctly that there has been no season in recent history with more than (or equal) 4 hurricanes building after September 6. This would indicate that we should take back from our right skew as with the the likelihood of having many hurricanes very close to each other is being decreased.
Current trends:
We are in the front half of the busiest month for hurricanes and the National Hurricane Center is not predicting any major hurricane building in the next 5 days (https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/gtwo.php?basin=atlc&fdays=5). They put 10% and 30% formation probability of a cyclone in the Atlantic, and they have 1 Storm in the Eastern Pacific (Julio), but they put very low probability into it turning into a major hurricane. Forecast: In August 5, they put an 85% probability that there will be an above average activity of hurricanes. Given that there has been already one hurricane, we decrease our probability of first bucket to 9%. Given that there has been no precedence of seeing >= 4 hurricanes after September 6, we seriously decrease the probability of 6 or more hurricanes happening in aggregate. For 3-4-5 we cannot really build a differentiated opinion as it is still very early to have strong priors. We put the major bulk of probability into 4 as this would be around 1 standard deviation away from historical mean, underlining that this hurricane season was more active than previous seasons. Furthermore, Colorado State sees 5 hurricanes as most likely, therefore we skew our predictions slightly towards 5 as opposed to 3. Updates: The Colorado State University has been publishing their updated forecasts in the beginning of each month, therefore we will be following closely when the next update will be uploaded (https://tropical.colostate.edu/forecasting.html).

Two things to recognize first are that the peak of hurricane season usually occurs around ~September 10, thus more than half of the season still remains. It's also relevant to recognize that the 2020 hurricane season is actually outpacing the very active 2005 season in terms of number of named storms (but not number of named hurricanes).  The latest NOAA update (August 6) is still predicting between 3-6 major hurricanes for the season this year. Considering we've only had 1 major hurricane to date, the upper bound of this range seems rather high. The 2005 hurricane season had a total of 7 major hurricanes, 5 of which had formed by September 5. The 2004 hurricane season, which was also quite active, had a total of 6 major hurricanes, 3 of which had formed by September 5.  On the contrary, the 2017 hurricane season is worth mentioning, with a total of 6 major hurricanes, but "only" 2 major hurricanes by 9/5. Generally speaking the development of major hurricanes is independent, and a lack of major hurricanes at the beginning of the season doesn't mean a lack of major hurricanes at the end, and vice versa. The 2005 and 2017 seasons both serve as good examples. In order to get a better of the current season, there are no current active systems but there are two "Invests" (potential systems) with one given a high probability of developing into a named storm. This invest is a "cape verde" which is where most long-range major categories typically develop from in the second half of the season so is certainly something to consider.  Preliminary forecast is given above, with most weight given on 4 and 5 as looking from historical data there have been ~3 major hurricanes following the halfway point in active seasons. I give the >=6 bucket less weight because that would mean 5 major hurricanes in the remainder of the season, which would be quite extreme considering that most of the activity will be occurring in the next month and half. I weight 5 a little bit higher than 3 simply because of the one Invest that is developing near the Cape Verde islands right now. To note, we have had one category 3 or higher ("Major hurricane") thus far this year (Hurricane Laura). Let's first arrive at a base rate.  Historically, since 1950, each year has seen an average of 2.74 major hurricanes with a std dev of 1.94. The NOAA has projected 3-6 major hurricanes this season as well as an overall extremely active season (Source: https://www.noaa.gov/media-release/extremely-active-hurricane-season-possible-for-atlantic-basin#:~:text=The%202020%20Atlantic%20hurricane%20season,of%20the%20busiest%20on%20record.&text=An%20average%20season%20produces%2012,%2C%204%2C%20or%205). Colorado state on August 5th, 2020 projected 5 such major hurricanes. Indeed, their most recent 2 week forecast also suggests a similar outlier year for major hurricanes. To also note, we are reaching the most active period for hurricanes historically (the September month) so just because we may see many hurricanes form during this period, doesn't mean we should necessarily aggressively skew higher if we do see many hurricanes. A simple historical histogram suggests that the number of major hurricanes is significantly right skewed. As such, we put more weight on the 4 bin compared to the 6 bin with most of our weight going into the 5 bin. The Colorado State researchers said that their 68% CI on august was 3 - 7. Given more time has passed and the prospects for an outlier year are higher now, I feel more confident in putting more probability mass (95%) into the 3+ bins.

Looking at this question again given the discrepancies between my forecast and the crowd. I'm still sticking to my original forecast that uses the historical base rates. However, I thought I would shift my forecast significantly toward the 2 or fewer bucket, given that we still haven't had a cat 3 hurricane and we are well into August. However, after looking at the data I don't think that would be a good idea. Here's why: Of the 20 years since 2000, there have been 3 or more cat 3 hurricanes 11 times. I looked at how many of those years have not had a cat 3 hurricanes until mid-August. Turns out, 2019, 2017, 2016, 2011, 2010, 2003, and 2001 all had their first cat 3+ storm after mid-August. So, going by the historical record, about 7/20 have not had a cat 3+ hurricane up to this point and still exceeded 2 hurricanes.  Given that, I'm going to leave my forecast where it is. I'm increasing my estimate slightly based on the continuation of high activity, although still remaining well below the crowd. Arguments for this to be an above-average year are sound: 
1) This year is off to a huge start: Looking at data since 1960 I observe that there isn't a strong correlation between early season activity and a strong year for major storms. 
2) conditions are favorable for hurricane formation with lots of hot water out there in the formation zone.
3) we are in ENSO-neutral conditions and if anything odds favor a female rather than male child later in the year.  Where I differ from the crowd is that I'm estimating a just-slightly-above-average season, so my numbers are lower. This is based on zero meteorological experience so I don't recommend anyone follow me in my suicide mission.  Posting some links for those who are interested in tracking the key ingredients for hurricane formation:  However, there is still a lot of warm-enough water out there (need >27.8C, the higher the better, if you're a hurricane) https://www.ospo.noaa.gov/Products/ocean/sst/contour/ Also the water needs to be >26.5-ish down to about 50m depth and high surface temperature is a good indication. Wind shear over most of the formation area needs to be low (looking for <10kts for formation of strong systems): http://trackthetropics.com/atlantic-wind-shear-maps/#targetText=When%20one%20hears%20the%20phrase,5%2C000%20feet%20above%20the%20surface.

My above predictions are fairly far removed from that of the crowd. I am more optimistic that the coming season will be less severe than some have suggested. Both my regression models and an aggregate of expert opinion seem to indicate that this season will bring a fair number of hurricanes. However, I think that the crowd's prediction that there is a 30% chance of 5 hurricanes and only a 1% chance of 2 or less is too pessimistic. Since there are no hurricanes developing as of 14/06 I fail to see why these predictions could be so high. That being said, the forecast does look odious and Atlantic sea temperatures are warmer than normal so I have tweaked my predictions upwards a little to account for this. I have outlined how I generated my predictions below. The first part of my prediction (40%) used a Linear Regression model to project the number of Cat. 3 hurricanes in 2020. The model uses data from 1969 to 2019 and tries to account for growth across the time period. Essentially, it uses a line of ‘best-fit’ to make a prediction for 2020. The model predicts that there will be 3.664 category 3 hurricanes in 2020 and I used a normal distribution formula to work out probabilities for each bin. I got the 1969-2019 data from Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantic_hurricane_season) Linear Regression Predictions: 2 or Fewer = 36%
3 = 23%
4 = 20%
5 = 13%
6 or More = 9% The second part of my model (40%) uses the average prediction by experts and institutions from around the world. Rather surprisingly the average prediction comes in only slightly higher than the linear regression model at 3.8 cat. 3 hurricanes. It is worth noting that of the 11 forecasts l looked at only 2 studies predicted more than 4 major hurricanes in the coming season. Again, I used a normal distribution formula to generate probabilities for each bin. It is likely that the experts will use different methods to generate probability distributions but I only had access to hurricane number predictions and therefore had to generate probabilities using my own methods. Source (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Atlantic_hurricane_season). Average of Expert Predictions (11 Institutions from around the world including the NOAA and the Met Office): 2 or Fewer = 32%
3 = 22%
4 = 21%
5 = 14%
6 or More = 10% It is interesting to compare the expert predictions to the best-fit projections I made in part one. As you can see, the aggregate expert prediction is not too far removed from the ‘mean regression’ prediction I made above. I think in some respects the seemingly over-pessimistic forecasts by the crowd may be due to too much focus on the NOAA prediction and fear inducing articles such as this - https://edition.cnn.com/2020/06/14/weather/hurricane-season-2020-records-forecast-june/index.html. I may be wrong, but the crowd's prediction that there is only a 1% chance of 2 or fewer cat. 3 hurricanes seems extreme and contrasts with recent history (Even if you take the last 21 years, there have been 2 or less hurricanes on eight occasions). The final part of my model (20%) uses a simple base rate for each bin over the last 21 years. This is a simple count of the occurrences of each bin over the last 21 years. Base Rate Probabilities: 2 or Fewer = 45%
3 = 15%
4 = 15%
5 = 15%
6 or More = 10%

Warmer-than-average sea surface temperatures in the tropical Atlantic Ocean and the Caribbean Sea, coupled with reduced vertical wind shear, weaker tropical Atlantic trade winds, and an enhanced west African monsoon all increase the likelihood for an above-normal Atlantic hurricane season. Similar conditions have been producing more active seasons since the current high-activity era began in 1995. [1] “NOAA’s analysis of current and seasonal atmospheric conditions reveals a recipe for an active Atlantic hurricane season this year,” said Neil Jacobs, Ph.D., acting NOAA administrator. [1] CSU’s forecast (published June 4, 2020) predicts a total of 19 named tropical storms (average is 12.1) for the year, of which 9 will become hurricanes (average is 6.4). Of the hurricanes that are expected to occur, 4 will turn into major hurricanes (average is 2.7). [2] NOAA’s initial forecast (published May 21, 2020) predicts a 60% chance of an “above-normal” season made up of between 13 and 19 named tropical storms. Of those storms, between 6 and 10 are likely to become hurricanes, and between 3 and 6 of those hurricanes could become major hurricanes (category 3, 4, or 5). First, here's the official NOAA forecast: https://www.noaa.gov/media-release/busy-atlantic-hurricane-season-predicted-for-2020#:~:text=May%2021%2C%202020%20An%20above,of%20the%20National%20Weather%20Service.&text=An%20average%20hurricane%20season%20produces,hurricanes%2C%20including%203%20major%20hurricanes. "NOAA’s Climate Prediction Center is forecasting a likely range of 13 to 19 named storms (winds of 39 mph or higher), of which 6 to 10 could become hurricanes (winds of 74 mph or higher), including 3 to 6 major hurricanes (category 3, 4 or 5; with winds of 111 mph or higher). NOAA provides these ranges with a 70% confidence. An average hurricane season produces 12 named storms, of which 6 become hurricanes, including 3 major hurricanes." Next I'll look at the outside odds: Based on the data I can find from some quick googling: The probability of major hurricanes has fluctuated a lot over the last hundred years. I assume that early on a lot of major hurricanes were missed because they were minor hurricanes when they hit land or they never hit land. So I'll ignore the data before about 1960 to just make up a completely random year. The distribution of major hurricanes 1960-2019 looks like this: 
<=2: 61%
3: 15%
4: 7%
5: 8%
>=6: 10% However it has fluctuated and it appears it's been higher than average in recent years (there was also another period of higher hurricane activity around 1945-1965): 
<=2: 45%
3: 15%	
4: 15%	
5: 10%
>=6: 15% So it appears that NOAA feels that this year is likely to be a bit higher than that. I'll assume that NOAA is right. They say that their 70% confidence interval is 3-6, so I'm going to assume that means that the probability of <=2 is 20% or less. (Their use of integers makes this an imprecise exercise).  So I'll assume something like this <=2: 20%
3: 25%	
4: 22%	
5: 17%
6: 8%
>=7: 8%

Using data from 1967 on from Wikipedia [1], we get an implied probability of:  2 or fewer: 33/53 = 62%
3:  8/53 = 15%
4:  3/53 = 6%
5:  5/53 = 10%
6+:  4/53 = 7%. Even if we look more recently it doesn't change much, though there is a decrease for 2 or fewer since (and including) 2000. The actual numbers are:  2 or fewer: 9/20 = 45%
3: 3/20 = 15%
4: 3/20 = 15%
5: 2/20 = 10%
6+: 3/20 = 15% To me, this suggests around a 50% chance of 2 or fewer and 50% for more than two. There seems to be no increased likelihood for another of the other categories so I'll split it evenly between them. I'm surprised so many people seem to think there will be (by historical standards) tons of hurricanes this year.
